results.title: Fashions, flowers and favourites
results.creator_credit: Syd Wood, Frank Killian, Movietonenews and Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: Shows numerous scenes in and around Melbourne (1962?) including activities such as the Melbourne Cup, sailing on Albert Park Lake, eating out and nightlife, the Miss Australia judging, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl and the Royal Botanic Gardens. Commentry by David Low and Bert Bryant.

results.title: Melbourne: Australia's garden city
results.brief_description: This panoramic tour of Victoria’s capital provides the viewer with a vibrant snapshot of Melbourne and its surroundings. Highlights of the tour include: a trip on Melbourne’s famous trams, beautiful parks and gardens, historic landmarks Como House and Werribee Park, Cook’s Cottage in the scenic Fitzroy gardens, Old Melbourne Gaol, the Dandenongs and Puffing Billy, Marysville, Sovereign Hill, Ballarat and surrounds, the National Wool Museum at Geelong, Phillip Island and the tranquil bush surroundings of Healesville Sanctuary.

results.title: The Penguin Video
results.brief_description: Phillip Island, with its rugged coastline, windswept beaches and sparkling water, attracts over a million visitors a year. From all over the world people come to witness Australia’s famous Penguin Parade. Peter Hosking is your guide to Phillip Island, a haven for over 200 species of birds and wildlife, including koalas, kangaroos, wallabies, wombats and fur seals. As the sun goes below the horizon, the world’s smallest penguins gather off-shore in large groups, waiting for the safety of darkness. The stage is set. The first come ashore and the parade of the little penguins begins! Rated: G

results.title: Wild life paradise
results.creator_credit: William M. Carty, Andrew J. Helgeson, Cinesound and Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: Sir Colin Mackenzie, famous surgeon and anatomist, thought that the study of Australia’s unique animals would help to understand the human body. He designed and made an arm splint after studying koalas stretching for gum tips. His specimens can be seen in the Institute of Anatomy in Canberra. In 1921, 78 acres of land in Healseville, Victoria, was presented to the late Sir Colin Mackenzie, to enable him to study Australian animals. The Sanctuary now shelters kangaroos, emus, platypus, goannas, many kinds of parrots, parakeets and other birds, tiger cats, wombats and koalas. Narrated by James Dibble. Suitable for 11-15 year-olds.

results.title: South west symphony
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow and Cinesound for the Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: A lyrical account of the scenic beauties of Victoria’s south west coastal region. Beginning with aerial shots and street scenes of the city of Melbourne and ending at historical Portland. Also visits many of the higlights along the Great Ocean Road, including Geelong, Lorne, Warrnambool and the 12 apostles. Cinematography by Ross King. Narrated by Len London. (Awards: AFI Silver award 1965 Travel Category)

results.title: The Magnetic north
results.creator_credit: Dennis Hill Productions, Lee Robinson, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Waratah Film Productions
results.brief_description: The attractions of the Northern Territory and the development of Darwin as a tourist centre. The tropical winter brings numerous visitors from the south. Anthropologists come to study Aboriginal rock paintings, crocodile hunters come in search of adventure, business men and tourists come eager to explore the by-ways of this part of Australia and to join the locals in their annual July Festival.

results.title: Lucky break at Wrest Point Casino
results.creator_credit: Peter Kay, Roger Clarke and Tasmanian State Film Unit
results.brief_description: A promotional film featuring Wrest Point Casino in Hobart. An American personality briefly gives his impressions of the city of Hobart, including the harbour, restaurants, the casino and the history of the city.

results.title: Polka-dotting Royal Exhibition Building
results.brief_description: Hugh McSpeeden is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor festival projections.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description:
Hugh (aka Humania) is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. A pioneer of outdoor projection in Australia, Hugh uses projectors as a musician would an instrument or a painter a palette, utilising lasers, slides, dyes, fluids and special effects to create unique images. He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.
description_for_label:

He uses as his canvas surfaces as diverse as buildings, landscapes and beaches.

  • The Light Show

His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor projections, such as those featured in White Night and Vivid.

results.title: Life
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Johnston, Mandy Walker, Elisa Argenzio, Australian Film Commission and Rough Trade Pictures
results.brief_description: Johnston’s debut feature following on from his award winning shorts ‘Night Out’ and ‘Eternity’, is a dynamic re-visioning of actor/playwright John Brumpton’s theatre piece “Containment” that focused on the situation of inmates in the segregated HIV positive section of an Australian prison. To describe Johnston’s beautifully composed, movingly rendered, emotionally shattering film as ‘an AIDS prison drama’ denies it the full range and reach of its compelling grip on any number of wider issues and universal concerns. Brumpton forcefully fleshes out the lead role of quick-tempered hardened Des, a crim who tests positive and is sent to T2 division. His relationship with his cell-mate Ralph is vividly evoked via subliminal flashbacks and interaction between themselves and amongst the other inmates of T2. Photography, Mandy Walker. Cast: John Brumpton, David Tredinnick, Robert Morgan, Belinda McClory, Noel Jordan.

results.title: Worse than Xmas
results.creator_credit: Julie Harris, Mandy Walker and Joanne Aslanis
results.brief_description: Waitress Angela (Kaarin Fairfax) rushes home to save a doomed relationship. When she fails, she agrees with her neighbour that Easter is the worst time of year, even worse than Christmas. The film follows the funny and inevitable diversions that Angela takes to make it through the breakup and start dating again.
